title: I hired an interior design firm to do remodeling in my house. The firm sent me bills and included charges for services that were
question: not done or were not completed. I paid the accurate parts of the bill. The firm sent my account to a collection agency which contacted me via phone and mail. I sent the collection agency a letter disputing the alleged charges. The collection agency insisted that the charges were valid.
answers:
You should of course seek help directly from an attorney that is experience in debt defense. It sounds like your issue with debt is limited to this one creditor and their collection company. In the event that your debt problems are more widespread, you should seek advice from a bankruptcy attorney.
However, for your reference, the California law that deals with the actions and practices of collection agencies is found in the Civil Code, starting with Section 1788.1. The Federal law that deals with the same subject, also applies in California and can be found at 15 United States Codes Section 1692.
Speak to an attorney. I think you'll find it helpful and effective.
Yes, No, Yes (and win), Dispute with each of the three agencies, The Rosenthal Act (but Federal Law applies too). You may have a great case here - fight back!

If you dispute the bill, in writing, if the collector reports the item to a credit reporting agency, it must also report that your liability is disputed. (Not all collection agencies report all accounts; the collection agency must pay a fee to the reporting agency in order to be able to report.

If the collector violates the federal Fair Credit Reporting Act, or the similar California statute, you may sue for damages, certain penalties and attorney's fees. Depending upon the legal theory you may consider including the original creditor, but that may be a matter of legal tactics.

If negative information is reported, you must dispute, in writing, that information. The credit reporting agency will then ask the "furnisher" of the information to verify the information. If the furnisher does so, you have a right to sue under 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2.
The California law is the Rosenthal Act.

Yes. Collection agency may place negative information on your credit report.
No Bill does not need to be paid if not correct. You must dispute the bill.
Yes. You may sue for damages incurred as result of knowingly placing or not retracting incorrect credit information.
Contact credit reporting agency and dispute the incorrect charges in writing.
Federal and state fair debt collection practices acts govern this area of law.
I'm changing this to debt defense and I think you'll be pleasantly surprised with the responses you get there.
The California Department of Consumer Affairs is where you need to go for answers to your questions.
